As students work through the course, their appreciation of how drugs affect the body in intended and unintended ways will increase.

Properties of liquids, solids, and gasses are also explored. This foundation is used to examine solubility, colligative properties of solutions, chemical reactions, quantum theory and atomic structure, and chemical periodicity. The general course topics include ante todo, en la universidad, la familia, de compras, en clase, las estaciones y el tiempo, ÁA comer!, de viaje, and los d’as festivos.

fca967fd-16a6-4907-8078-6f2891f5dac8.description: Building on Anatomy and Physiology I, the course provides an examination of major parts of the body and how they work independently as well as together. Major topics covered in the course are the cardiovascular system (blood, heart, blood vessels, and circulation), lymphatic system, respiratory system, digestive system, immunity, nutrition, metabolism and temperature regulation, urinary system, water, electrolytes, acid-base balance, reproductive system, human development, growth, and aging.
fca967fd-16a6-4907-8078-6f2891f5dac8.name: Anatomy and Physiology II (BIO202) OOSL-0030 (v.1)

eb090359-0638-4f20-b31d-607317c7be9e.description: The course teaches non-medical personnel to recognize and treat life-threatening emergencies, assess the victim, and treat cardiovascular emergencies as well as external and internal injuries. It covers remote locations; pregnancy and childbirth; respiratory and cardiovascular emergencies; choking; AED usage; shock, heat, and cold; external injuries; internal injuries; burns; musculoskeletal injuries; poisoning, substance abuse, and bites; behavioral emergencies; and rescuing and moving victims.

Topics include functions and graphs, differential equations, antiderivatives, chain rule, integration by parts, definite integrals, fundamental theorem of calculus, volume, net change and displacement, logistic growth, work, arc length and surface of revolution, parametric integrals, polar integrals, sequences, series, and sums.
f4b40eaf-8542-42d0-82af-5ec46ab5ab2c.name: General Calculus II (MAT251) OOSL-0019 (v.1)

The general course topics include kinematics, motion in one and two dimensions (including Newton's Laws), dynamics, energy and power, particles, linear momentum, gravity, fluids, relativity, oscillations, waves, and thermodynamics and heat. Prerequisites: Calculus I (or its equivalent).
7195f701-e759-4202-a8ea-94eb8f85761d.name: General Physics I (PHY250) OOSL-0023 (v.1)

Topics include electrostatics, conductors, and capacitors; electric circuits; magnetostatics; electromagnetism; wave motion; physical optics; geometric optics; atomic physics; quantum effect; and nuclear physics.
